text: This book was a collection of around 3 years worth of articles by Jeremy Clarkson for a Newspaper in UK. And many of the articles are from continuous weeks. Clarkson is a funny guy and it shows in his observations but seeing how the articles were originally written between 2001 and 2003 and I read the book in 2018, it was already quite dated but still fun enough to read and finish.I liked it but since it's not a book in the traditional sense I could only finish couple of chapters at a time. If you wanna read some funny thought pieces go for this. Or go for some other book but keep on reading.People who don't read generally ask me my reasons for reading. Simply put I just love reading and so to that end I have made it my motto to just Keep on Reading. I love to read everything except for Self Help books but even those once in a while. I read almost all the genre but YA, Fantasy, Biographies are the most. My favorite series is, of course, Harry Potter but then there are many more books that I just adore. I have bookcases filled with books which are waiting to be read so can't stay and spend more time in this review, so remember I loved reading this and love reading more, you should also read what you love and then just Keep on Reading.

This was not intended as a book, it is a collection of articles written by Jeremy Clarkson for the Sunday Times. I often violently disagree with his viewpoint but he is tremendously entertaining and very funny. We need more commentators like him to stimulate public debate which is all too often stifled by the PC brigade afraid to offend anyone. Jeremy Clarkson doesn't care a hoot what you think, which is refreshing.

Things Jeremy Clarkson hates: women, lesbians, foreigners and effeminate footballers.Things Jeremy Clarkson likes: 70s prog rock, travel and Jeremy Clarkson.The most disjointed and dis-satisfying collection of short essays I've ever read. And I do mean short: at one point Clarkson mentions he's being paid to hit a set word limit, which explains why all the articles end abruptly and in most cases with non-sequiturs.

One thing should be made clear: Jeremy Clarkson is basically an internet troll in real life, i. e. he's to automotive journalism what the late Seth Putnam was to music. The only difference's a matter of subtlety.Since it hence follows that finding anything Clarkson says publically to be insightful is more or less the same thing as deriving your political views from the lyrics Seth Putnam wrote for his band Anal Cunt, how does a book entirely consisting of Mr. Clarkson's alleged opinions read?Not how I expected it to, that's for certain. Most of it basically comes across as the written-down rants of some drunken bar patron on various topics, but there's also assorted humourous anecdotes from working at the BBC and his usual "make sarcastic comments about ugly sports cars by referring to national stereotypes about the countries they're made in" shtick. Then, occasionally he'll suddenly write something that even I find to have some seriously worthwhile insight in it, and even stylish writing. The piece on his stay in Basque Country, for example, develops a "Hunter Thompson for dummies" feel. I don't know how he does it.The funniest thing about the book, though is something that I'm not even sure is intentional: At least a third, possibly even a half, of the articles concerned things nobody outside of Britain has likely ever heard of or will even ever want to care about... which makes the title decidedly ironic. How stereotypically British is that?

Lent to me by someone who said it was hilarious. Well, I did crack a smile a couple of times. Clarkson is that “Top Gear” guy on BBC TV; I watched for a few minutes once then switched him off. Here he is writing a column for the Sunday Times from 2001 to 2003, and these are mild diatribes about, oh, everything you would expect a slightly-right-of-centre guy to rant about if you stood him a pint in the pub. They are all exactly 3 ½ pages long, so he must have been held to a pretty tight word count, which might explain why so many lack any real punch-line.

I would never thought that I will give this book a 5-star rating. But his humour is so brilliant, that I have to do this absurdity and put him on a shelf with 1984 or Pride and Prejudice. I think he would also laugh at this.

From Top Gear's most entertaining presenter, this book collects a bunch of short pieces Jeremy Clarkson wrote for the paper.As an Ugly American, or at least an Average-Looking American, I'll say that there are definitely a lot of references I didn't really understand. I don't blame the book for that. I mean, we're talking about London cultural references from 2001. Even the U.S. equivalents probably wouldn't make a ton of sense to people around here. If I compared a politician from 2001 to Limp Bizkit, well, let's just not even take it any further.I wonder if Americans really are so bad about learning other cultures. Or, to put it differently, is this one of the few cases where it's not so much our fault?Consider:A Forbes article from 2013 pointed out that the U.S. is the only "Advanced" economy in the world that does not have any mandated paid vacation. Additionally, U.S. law does not enforce any holiday vacation while other "advanced" economies mandate between 5 and 13, these in addition to the required paid holidays.Apparently there are also 5 countries that pay HIGHER wages for vacation days to help offset expenses incurred while traveling. Consider Also:When it comes to sheer size, it's no small feat just to get across the U.S. In fact, if you lay Texas over Europe, you'll cover parts of France, Belgium, The Netherlands, Germany, Switzerland, the Czech Republic, Austria, Italy, and just a bit of Poland for good measure.Texas is a big-ass state, but it's only 8-10% of the entire U.S. landmass, depending on whether you count Alaska and Hawaii. I'm not trying to use the old argument that other countries are too far away. I don't know why they built Spain way the hell over there, but what's a fella to do?What I am trying to say is that, culturally, your traveling miles go a lot further in Europe than they do in the U.S. You can make your way to a lot of very different spots with their own, much older cultures while actually putting far fewer miles under your belt.Consider Finally: The Dollar is about .75 Euros. It's been this way or worse since I've been old enough to travel on my own.I'm not suggesting that any one of these factors should prevent Americans from exploring the world. When you consider, as is done in some of the book's last essays, how much easier travel has become with the rise of the jet engine, there's not much excuse....except when one considers that the average American is dealing with all three of these factors, at best. I feel pretty strongly that most of the people I know, most of whom are Americans AT LEAST as ugly as I am, would be happy to visit places outside the U.S. for extended periods. Given the opportunity, many, many would go. But I have to say, it limits the desire to learn about a culture when you'll only read about it in books and see brief glimpses on TV. It's tough to learn French when you figure you'll maybe get to Paris for four days sometime in your life. Or, [shudder] Canada.I feel The System, The Man, The Whatever It Is in America really lends itself to jumping on a plane for a few hours, spending two days a couple states away, somewhere that has beaches if you don't have those, or somewhere that has nice beaches if you have suck beaches, and then coming back after a long weekend. Anyway, for better or worse, Top Gear is my primary exposure to European culture at this point in my life. God help us all.

3.5 stars for The World According to Clarkson. I must say, reading this book took me what felt like a very long time to finish! I was shocked (and slightly disheartened) to find that it was only around 320 pages long (reading it on a Kindle meant I was totally oblivious to the page count). This book is, in a nutshell, a series of entries written by Clarkson which discuss his views on certain aspects of life! The reason I read this is because I watched the 20th anniversary of Millionaire hosted by Clarkson, and after absolutely LOVING it (and him!), it provoked me to buy one of his books. It is not a book I would typically read with my tastes but I thought I would give it a go nonetheless. Personally, I think my reactions to this book fall into three different stages!Stage 1I STARTED it and I began to really, really enjoy it. Jeremy Clarkson, whilst controversial, is an absolutely hilarious man and his honesty is incredibly contagious. A lot of his opinions I would completely NOT agree with but one can still read them knowing that they are in jest! Some other things he says, however, are (admittedly) 100% true and would do the world some good to be said. If nothing else, Clarkson encourages the reader go through life with open honesty.Additionally, the comedy levels in this are off the scale. Some chapters had me laughing less often than others...but those that WERE really funny had me guffawing. If you are in need of some light relief, this will be the book for you!Stage 2I was getting on for halfway through and I started to get a little bit bored. Even despite my disappointment at realising my ten days of reading were in fact only for a 320 page book, I still think this was too long. For me, it ended up getting a bit repetitive: NOT to the extent that I wasn’t enjoying the book anymore; just to the point where there would be some chapters I would only glance at. This doesn’t mean the book was any harder work! I was just chuckling and loving the chapters I did really enjoy, and skimming through the ones I didn’t.Stage 3Then RIGHT at the end (I had about another 25% to go), I decided to just go ahead and finish it so I skimmed through to the end. For this book, do not be afraid to skim through some parts! A lot of this book is full of wit and very worth it; however, whenever Jeremy Clarkson started talking about politics (for example), I completely zoned out. This isn’t particularly the fault of the book because, in general, there are few things which interest me less than politics; but it is undeniable that certain parts of this book were a lot LESS interesting than other parts. I will admit that getting to the end did require some pushing through as I felt that it had been going on for long enough. If this book had been shorter, I would have appreciated the GOOD chapters even more and been able to look on the book as a whole with a fresher, more positive light. There was a SMALL element of it getting all too much the same by the end.Yet I shall not be ending this review on a negative because I DID enjoy this book and I do think it has a lot of merit! Here are a few of my favourite quotes:(This is about people giving directions.)“...some launch immediately into a bunch of militaristic directions, involving clear, concise hand signals and bushy-topped trees at nine o’ clock. But that’s no help because you won’t be listening. It is a known medical fact, and it has been so since the dawn of time, that a man will hear the first word and then shut down.”“Why do I need to have a man poke about in my mouth with a sharpened screwdriver when I know that my teeth will last about 50,000 years longer than the rest of me?Nobody dies of tooth decay. It’s always some other part of the body that gives up, but despite this we don’t go to the doctor twice a year demanding a full service. Come on, doc, there’s nothing obviously wrong but I want you to examine every single bit of me minutely. I want X-rays and then I want to see your hygienist, who will spray jets of ice-cold grit up my backside.No, we go to the doctor only when something is wrong and that’s how it should be at the dentist.”“...there’s no such thing as an accident these days. If you trip over a paving stone or eat a dodgy piece of meat, there will be an enquiry, someone will be culpable, and steps will be taken to ensure it doesn’t happen again....Nobody is allowed to die either. George Carman QC, for instance, pegged out at the age of 71, which is not a bad innings. But oh no. His death has been chalked up to cancer as though it might have been avoided if he’d not eaten cheese and broccoli.” That above one, in particular, is very true! I have seen examples of this in my life before and I am sure many others have too.“The human being is programmed to take risks. Had our ancestors spent their days sitting around in caves, not daring to go outside, we’d still be there now....Telling us that speed kills and asking us to slow down is a bit like asking us to ignore gravity.”In other words, half of these precautions people set are pointless. Live life without worrying! Life’s too short to worry about the health defects of cheese and broccoli (quoting back the other point).“I have just finished a book by Philip Roth...it’s almost as though Roth rang the publishers and asked: ‘How long would you like my next novel to be?’ And when they said 250 pages, he said ‘Oh good, I’ve finished.’”In short, this is a brilliantly funny book which can teach you a lot of stuff to apply in life (and a lot of stuff NOT to apply in life!). My advice upon reading this book would be a) separate his jokes from what he ACTUALLY means, and b) don’t be afraid to skim through the marginally more uninteresting parts. Overall, however, thumbs up to this! Absolutely fantastic.

After reading a bunch of dull books, this is just what the doctor ordered. I like Clarkson anyways which helps, he's funny enough to make a show about cars seem interesting and that's good enough for me!This is a collection of articles he wrote for the Sunday Times back in the early noughties. Made me chuckle a fair few times. Some articles were written as speculation, like what if Ebola got on a plane....switch Ebola for Coronavirus and were living it today. Makes me feel a bit funny when I read stuff like that!Don't read if you don't like Clarkson or are a bit of a snowflake, as you won't like this, you'll get triggered and upset yourself.If you have a sense of humor though, crack on!

This is collection of Jeremy Clarkson's Sunday Times columns from January 2001 to December 2003. Each one only amounts to about 4 pages in print, so it's very easy (and preferable) to read in small snippets.Most people seem to enjoy Clarkson on Top Gear, but his writing you either love or hate. It follows that same wise cracking style as on TV, but I found it can get a tad annoying if you read to much at one sitting. In these collected columns I think he manages to insult just about every nationality and ethnic group. He pokes fun at himself just as much, so the overall feeling on finishing this book was "why are we all so stupid at times" :)One for fans only I think.

I would say this is an okay book. It does have many humorous and sarcastic incidents or narrations. However, there were way too many things that I was clueless about. Some of that I agree is due to the lack of political/ geographical knowledge about the UK but most of it is because I'm not a native from there. So, a lot of things that the people from the UK might get, just flew over the head. When I was reading those bits, I would realise that it is meant to be a sarcastic remark at someone or it is something funny, but I don't get it. This made a good part of the book kinda boring.Another thing is that since it is a collection of columns from back in the early 2000s, I couldn't recollect many incidents that kinda left me clueless about what Jermy was trying to say. Overall, read it if you are from the UK and you will like it and for the rest of them, this can be something when you need a light read and something humorous to pass time.

I couldn't be more different from Jeremy Clarkson - I'm a woman, a feminist (these two don't always go together),a bit of a Leftie, interested in green issues and I can't drive. However, as I'm currently on a mission to read every book in our house before I'm allowed to buy any more, it had to be Jeremy's turn eventually.The book is a collection of his columns from The Sunday Times from 2001 to 2003. It was published in 2005 which meant that some of the events mentioned were quite a while ago at the time of publication, but reading it in 2011 means that I had no idea about some of the news stories he refers to.This is no great loss though as most of his columns are pretty much the same. This isn't quite as obvious when reading them a week apart in the paper, but reading this many at one time makes it very plain indeed.Some of it is mildly amusing, but only one paragraph in one column made me laugh out loud (it was about passports for donkeys - I like donkeys).So I've read it and it was ok - can't really say any more than that.

Good thing I read this at home and never on public transport because it made me snort several times. Yes, Clarkson is judgmental, opinionated and sometimes downright insulting...but his acerbic wittiness can be highly amusing. The book is actually a collection of articles that appeared in the Sunday Times in the early 2000s. The article-length chapters make for easy reading (each rant about a specific topic isn’t longer than 6 pages 😅). It is basically a commentary on current affairs at the time, which I found interesting. However, it also means that I didn’t always know what he was talking about and putting the book down to google names/events can be tiresome. This is the reason for taking down a star. At one point I was sure I’d be taking down another star for Clarkson’s dismissive views on environmental destruction. But at some point between July and October 2001, something made him change his mind, and I respect a person who can admit they were wrong.

An entertaining and easy read. A selection of articles by Jeremy Clarkson, most of which aren't longer than 3,5 pages and it's topics vary from personal anecdotes, to opinion pieces about everything from wold politics to food, child care, and of course engineering. It's fast and entertaining, even though it's not up there with the works of Aristotle in terms of depth (neither does it aim to be). I occasionally found myself thinking more deeply about the various problems mentioned. I also found the writing style enjoyable but that may not be the case for most, but I'm quite sure it will be enjoyed by those who read mostly British authors. So all in all a worthwhile read, even if you are not a fan of Top Gear because it talks about cars as much as you might find yourself discussing the latest developments in biology.
Hilarious. With a lot of good info in it.

A collection of newspaper columns written by Jeremy Clarkson, pulled together to create this book. The trouble is that these are mostly observations and opinions on current affairs nearly twenty years ago, so much of it appears very dated. If I’d read it nearer the time it was published, it may have been worth 4 stars. My fault, sorry Jezza.It’s interesting from a time-travel point of view though. In one chapter Clarkson is complaining about having to go to pubs to eat, because restaurants that allow you to smoke are becoming few and far between. You ain’t seen nothin’ yet, I thought.Each chapter is exactly 3.25 pages long, hence the length of the original newspaper article. For that reason, this makes a decent read if you’re continually being interrupted or I dare say, having a crap. Again, sorry Jezza.

I like marmite and I like Clarkson. Arrogance is his principal virtue, sprinkled with a misogynistic, antediluvian morality, but his stoic refusal to accept the wokeness of modern society is, for me, mostly where we see eye to eye.That said, I was going to give this book only 2 stars because it’s actually just a lazy re-hash of columns he wrote for The Times 20 years ago. Out of date and past its sell-by probably. But as I found myself looking forward to the next short chapter I thought no, I still enjoy agreeing with him, and his style still makes me chuckle.Woke was not a word in common usage 20 years ago, but if it had been and you found it at best a misguided persuasion and at worst an offensive one, this would have been the book for you. And for me it still is, so 4 stars after all.

It's a collection of his newspaper columns. It's very easy to pick up and put down, and it doesn't matter where you start or stop. It'd be great in a guest room, or on a trip where you expect to be interrupted a great deal. Some are quite funny, some go right over my head as I'm not British and have little idea who or what he's talking about. I found the statement "I've never hit anyone" in one of his stories to be funny in light of why we know watch Grand Tour instead of Top Gear to see Clarkson and his mates.

While Clarkson's writing was as witty and enjoyable as I hoped it would be after watching him on Top Gear for the last decade, I didn't enjoy the book as wholly enjoyable as I had anticipated. The format was better suiting to reading in small bursts rather than as a complete novel. I also found it hard to immerse myself when I know nothing of the goings on of 2001 England and all of the current events he was alluding to. I think if those two factors did not exist, I would have greatly enjoyed this book, rather than just enjoying his writing style.

Jeremy Clarkson is a funny guy with a larger than life personality. It seems he has an opinion on everything and each opinion is more outrageous than the last. The World According to Clarkson is a collection of his newspaper rants and it runs the full spectrum. I really liked “We must work harder to get rid of cricket” as I never got why that sport was ever popular. Overall, this is a funny read that you can put down for a year, come back to it and continue to laugh. I think Jeremy makes a good point. We have to laugh at ourselves… Or else he might write a book about you!

I really enjoyed The World According to Clarkson. Since the chapters are all really short it was very comfortable to read. As expected from Jeremy a lot of his columns were hilarious but to my great delight some were also thought-provoking. Because the different columns were written from 2001 to 2003 it was quite interesting to be reminded of what happened at that time. Sometimes I was honestly surprised that certain topics were already discussed back then. Altogether The World According to Clarkson is everything you´d expect and hope for from Jeremy Clarkson.

JC says so many things, like shower thoughts, that people really should consider. If not for consideration, then just to hear another view. So far the most profound thing is what he says on the subject of the Queen (no puns). That she has the power to dissolve parliament but has such a strong will, that she doesn't. We could all learn a thing or two from that especially. And turtles. And travelling and teeth and lotteries and Mandela and Germans. Every little bit of a clever view helps when you are nowhere near a blinkers-off lifestyle.

I have always liked the stuff Jeremy did on TV. Everything. But still, it came as a surprise to me how much I like his writing. Sure, I don't agree with everything he says (and I think that he does neither), but at times when I'm too tired or preoccupied to concentrate on a complex novel, it was really nice to have something witty in a short form so well written. So I'm giving this book 5 stars and continuing on with the next. I just found myself more than once carrying one with one more and one more with these articles way after bedtime. I think you should give it a try too.

I got aquainted with Jeremy Clarkson via Top Gear so I am more than familiar with his style and sense of humor. Long rants, sarcastic and with a heavy dose of humble truth, all made better by listening to them with his voice in my head as I read through. I am sure I would have enjoyed it much more if I had been following the events and the commentary as they were happening, alas I wasn't even in the UK at the time. Fun read nonetheless.

Barely amusing, this compilation of Clarkson columns is perfectly suited for the toilet. No, not to be used as paper, but to be skimmed briefly, eliciting mild snorts, and then to be left alone for quite some time. Since these pieces are written as columns it fails utterly as a book, but that does not mean Clarkson is without wit. That wit, however, is simply best consumed in extremely small doses. In short, don't bother paying money for it.

I thought I'd read this before, but apparently I'd only started reading it on the previous occasion. Anyway, this was enjoyable. While it's obviously a little dated, given that the articles were originally published between 2001 and 2003, that just makes it more interesting when he starts talking about the possibility of future pandemics. Quite touching in places, too, particularly in the articles about Concorde.

If one wants to become a more engaging, enjoyable anything, they need to find the master in their field and learn well. Aspiring authors and journalists need to learn from Jeremy Clarkson. Yeah, yeah, yeah - I know. He's fairly crazy. But even with full knowledge of this, it's nearly impossible to put his books down. It's because he's THAT good.

If you're an American you probably don't read The Sunday Times, which Clarkson writes weekly for. Personally I enjoy Clarkson's humor and his outlook on the world so I found this an entertaining read. The chapters are each a small article so it's nice to read when you only have a few minutes at a time.

Gloriously funny. I would have said he's completely underrated as a comedian, but there's the fact that he's running his own comedy show, although he's disguised it as a car programme. I think I have found myself a kindred spirit.

It's interesting to see that the issues we are worried about today were also present 15 years ago in a very similar form. Clearly we don't learn! This collection of Clarkson's columns are frank and funny.

Amusing read. Due to the age of the book (and my age), a fair bit was commentary on political happenings at the time, which I just didn't follow. A nice easy read to chip away at over breakfast in the morning.

An absolutely hilarious collection of Jeremy Clarkson's Sunday Times articles from circa 2001-2003. While some do get slightly repetitive (generally, they are just him ranting on about a random topic), I was in stitches reading most of it.

I read this after watching Clarksons Farm and loving Jeremy's humour. This book disappointed, originating as columns in the newspaper, it didn't translate well to book form and just seemed endlessly boring and conceited.
Good read if you are up for his very direct and sometimes controversial attitudes towards things.
Downright hilarious, if "Top-Gear" humour is your thing.
Classic Jeremy Clarkson humor a bit dark in some sense. loved it
Boring with some scattered funny parts.
You can hate him or love him, but he is always spot on and hilariously funny ... except if you don't like him.
There were a few laughs for me, but it fizzled and I stopped around 70% in.
Hilarious and witty. A very different perspective.
It's a very entertaining book that will keep you reading and gives you a smile on your face.
If you like Clarkson & his idiosyncratic behaviour, then you'll absolutely enjoy this book. Hilarious!
Funny reading. Read in Ukrainian translation, liked the way it was written and translated.Nothing deep in a book though.
Well written. Okay, so I disagree with some of his opinions, and others haven't aged well (written in 2001-2003), but some are still alarmingly accurate and relevant.
Funny enough. Probably would have been more amusing to have read it at the time it was published as it’s all based on current affairs in the UK in 2001-03
The start of an incredible line of enjoyable reading.
Very entertaining, he can really write
really bad
Ranting, sarcasm all from the Sun. I must have enjoyed reading this. Just look how long it took to read it.
It's by Clarkson, so funny at times, annoying at other times, exactly what I expected.
I don't think I'm English enough to get most of the humor here - it was mildly amusing, but I could tell I was missing out on the main point of most of the stories.
The first and the last articles are quite nice and witty, but everything in-between is unfortunately rather narrow-minded for my taste..
Jeremy as always hilariously describe world around him. Would read it again.
A bit outdated but still quite funny and interesting. It's also interesting how the author's views changed in the past 20 years - some of which were quite 'controversial'

I have had this book on my shelf for a very long time, after initially knicking it from my Mum. Never in that time had I felt the need to open the book and check the format, as I had always naively believed that it was an Autobiography. After finding out it was simply a collection of his articles for the Sunday Times, I was disappointed but ploughed on.These articles are from 2001 to 2003 which presented two issues for me;1. I was between the ages of 5 and 8 at that time and therefore unaware of the current affairs - appauling, I know. That meant that I didn't know about a lot of the events & happenings that were referenced and ended up a little lost at times2. Attitudes were different. The way he talked about certain things didn't sit right with me in the 2020 landscape. For example; suggesting that Britain wasn't sure about it's identity anymore because of the growing number of Mosques, referring to heterosexual sex between a man and a woman as 'proper sex' and describing graduates from Brunel as 'brown and yellow faces'. In addition to this, he enjoyed discussing women's appearances, the size of their breasts or them being 'too fat' for certain clothing items.Most of the time, in the present, I quite like Jeremy Clarkson. So please don't think I've picked up this book just to criticise and complain about him. There were some points when I found his articles funny. I even find him funny in the present day, however you cannot get away from the fact that he is an upper middle class, rich, white male with some very stereotypical views.I won't be picking up the rest of his books - mostly because I don't like the format. But if he ever comes out with an actual autobiography, I would definitely consider picking it up.
Ok

The World, according to Clarkson, is a place that can do with a bit of improvement. He also knows the best person for the job, or at least for dispensing advice on how to go about it. Some say that he eats bitumen for breakfast, and that if he could be bothered, he would break the sound barrier on a lawn-mower. All Clarkson can say is that he is called ...Clarkson.And so, in this collection of his 2001-2003  Sunday Times  columns, Clarkson holds forth on what is wrong with Religion, Jeffrey Archer, the Queen, the French, Capitalism, Britney Spears, the Slow Food Movement, Communism, Dentists, David Beckham, Science, the Russians, Astrology, Hitler, the RSPCA, the Labour Party, Cricket - and then he moves on to the second chapter. And apparently a lot is wrong, with a lot of the world, which makes for some entertaining reading. The Top Gear team travels plenty around the world, so Clarkson is well-placed to share some handy hints- if asked to stop on the border between Switzerland and Austria, one should always stop, because "I have no idea what  'Achtung'  means, except that it usually precedes a bout of gunfire followed by many years of digging tunnels."As befits newspaper columns, even the chapter titles are catchy ("Men, You Have Nothing to FEAR But Acronyms") and the fixed length of the columns means that this is a perfect bedside book. I'm not very keen on 'audio' books, but this might probably work even better in that medium- with Clarkson doing the narration.

"Is it very informative?" "No. It isn't." "Does Clarkson sound very matured?" "Bah, he's Clarkson. 'Matured' is the last word that comes to my mind when I try to think about an adjective to describe Jeremy Clarkson!" "Do you respect his opinions?" "Nay! Nay! Nay! Big No!" "Then why did you award a fu**ing five star rating to this book on good reads, mate?" "Eh... I liked it so much. Well, it's a great book to read!" Jezza is a funny little schoolboy trapped inside the body of a middle-aged man! He doesn't frame opinions in his mind and deliver them expecting to ink new chapters to the story of mankind. He frames opinions just to make people laugh out loud. He has great writing skills, and extremely great sense of humour. I did a huge mistake! I took this book with me to read it during a long train journey. All I did from the beginning to the end of this book was wrapping my lips over my teeth, and trying to construct a wall that would stop the huge waves of laughter from blasting out of my mouth loudly. This book never sounds brilliant. This book sounds foolish and crazy at many pages. But, as Clarkson has added the strong essence of his humour to each and every page of this book, this book sounds absolutely great! I would say, this book is a great therapist to the subconscious mind. After a long week, just stretch your legs, have a cup of coffee, and start reading this book; you'll literally laugh out loud at every single page, and you'll forget about all your tiredness and other side effects of hard work! Great book it's!

When I told my friend, who is also a big Top Gear fan, that J. Clarkson had written a book, he ordered it that day off of amazon. When he was done, he let me borrow it and, OH MY GOD. J.Clarkson is hilarious. There are actual several books, as they are just collections of his column in the Sunday Times, and this is the first. He covers a variety of subjects, including his chickens being eaten by foxes and his daughter being a fatty. No joke. Unfortunately since I didn't own the book I couldn't underline my favorite parts, but I did keep a collection of my favorite quotes:"real art, like real jeans, never goes out of fashion""I like 1970s rock music, and I'm not ashamed to admit it""all the funniest people in life are abject and total failures""i spend my life driving quickly, which is why i have a 1970s haircut""if anything, there was even more time in my twenties than there had been in my childhood, largely because i wasted to little of it by sleeping""i like a book that becomes more important in my life than life itself"my goal is to get my own copies off all his books, so I can underline and notate freely. I'm really excited about "I Know You Got Soul" where he talks about great machines. WOO!

Newspaper columns.  I like Jeremy Clarkson's books. I don't always agree with him but I like his writing. Sometimes he can be perfectly sensible. Other times ridiculously blinkered. He's funny, entertaining, irritating, opinionated (as everyone should be) although at times his opinions should be tempered with an open mind and facts (as should everyone's) and he's passionate about the things he cares about.  His books are divided into three categories.Car reviews There is a review of a car followed by a more normal article. I tend to skip the car part in these book and just read the article bit.Newspaper column collectionsLove these ones. I laugh at one column, nod in agreement at another, shake my head in disbelief at some and generally have a good time reading them. As he has said in interviews the columns don't necessarily reflect his true opinion so do remember some of those controversial columns are deliberate attempts to rile people. And some are real. Despite occasional disagreements i still enjoy his books immensely. Subject booksNot columns but books about one thing. So his motorworld book or i know you've got soul are about specific things.Overall I have enjoyed reading Jeremy Clarkson's books over the years and I always look forward to a new one.

After having read and reviewed the Kindle sample unfavourably - which was a very mean free sample, consisting of only the first and arguably worst three pages of the whole book - I was given this paperback. I've only slightly revised my opinion as many of these Sunday Times articles are barely worth printing in a newspaper, let alone compiling into a book. True, there were a few slight chuckles in places, maybe even a few semi-eye-opening stories such as the one about donkeys needing a passport in UK and I think there was even a mildly profound article which set me thinking somewhere near the end. For the most part though, this is clearly a facile moneyspinner of a book which revisits old territory (such as the Concorde) almost verbatim from Clarkson's other books. JC's super-exaggerated style becomes quite tiresome quite quickly and after a while, this reader just got annoyed by his middle-class woes and was left wondering how he can lead such a life full of such wonderful and interesting experiences, yet write such bad-tempered tosh about them. 6.5/10

"The World According to Clarkson" is a rather decent and amusing collection of Top Gear host Jeremy Clarkson's columns in the Sunday Times(originally published sometime around 2001-03) and each article is around 600-1000 words. Being an Asian, I struggled with this book. So, I did not always get what Jeremy Clarkson was saying over half of the time. I had to google certain words and names like "Nimbyism" and "Myra Hindley". I'm sure I'd enjoy the book more if I were from Europe as there are an extensive use of British and European references. Nevertheless, it was a funny read with some laugh-out-loud moments. And from some reviews that I've read, 8 out of 10 Europeans definitely enjoyed it. I believe this is the first volume in the series and there are many more books out there by Clarkson bearing the this title. But don't read the book if you are easily offended. Mr.Clarkson is a frank man indeed!

The World According to Clarkson is a selection of the best of Clarkson's work. I found it difficult to get into the swing of reading short articles, as I usually stick to novels. A lot of his views are hilarious, and I worried myself by agreeing with him on a couple of points, but I think that is part of Clarkson's wit. Shocking opinions abound in this collection, but they often seem to be included to shock, worded in the way that will get maximum reaction. Some of the articles are dated, and are not as funny because they are topical to the time, or to the region, and I am not an Englishman. However, just as many of this articles describe things that are still topical, such as global warming, technology and being a father. Although I enjoyed this book, I probably won't hunt down any other The World According to Clarkson books - but I would be interested in reading something that isn't a collection of articles.

Selection of Sunday Times columns between 2001 & 2003, some topics therefore are a bit outdated, but it's interesting to read and say: ow, I remember! Nationalities, politics or very common and recognisable situations are being commented in a typicall Clarkson way: he doesn't mince his words, shamelessly spills out everything that comes to mind which sometimes can be quite offensive, but most of the time is witful and even hilarious. The humor is already in the titles of the chapters 'If only my garden grew as well as the hair in my ears'. Just to show how Clarkson mocks the world, in one chapter he tries to find out why English fight. He thinks it's caused by unintelligence. His children, aged 7 and 8, fight all the time. America, a new country is 'full of relatively daft people, it doesn't have the wisdom or experience to construct a sensible response. So when it's prodded, it lashes out with its jets abnd its aircraft carriers.'Easy and fun read, use of slang.

I'm an American who has only recently discovered "Top Gear" and Mr. Clarkson. And even though I don't consider myself a car person, I really like the show. This book has very little to do with cars, and is a collection of Clarkson's newspaper columns from 2001-2003. That made the book pretty easy to read, you can easily just read for a few minutes for one of the articles, or as long as you would like. I found myself thinking "just one more before I go to sleep" and then another, and another... The topics cover a pretty wide range from politics, to gardening. I really agree with Clarkson on the need to achieve greatness. To build things that are awe-inspiring, even if they aren't the most practical or cost effective. He has a few articles about the Concorde late in the book that are spot on. But even when I didn't agree, I still found it an interesting and fun read.

I really enjoyed this book. It doesn't hurt that the entire time I read it it was entirely in his voice. I have not read a book like this in the past where I could pick up and put it down every few pages if needed. Keep in mind this is really just a collection of his articles and some of them are dated or very specific to regional politics that can be unfamiliar to those outside of the UK or Europe in general. Each article/'chapter' ranges from 3-4 pages so it makes it a very quick read. If you like Clarkson's humor on Top Gear, this is a good read, but if you are looking for something specifically related to Top Gear, you will barely find more than 2-3 mentions within the book and not a single article revolves around it. To me this was not an issue because funny is funny, no matter the topic as long as you can keep me laughing, and this did.

Bored…I love watching Jeremy Clarkson on “Top Gear.” He’s boorish, he’s insensitive, he’s politically incorrect and there’s always a good chance he’s going to stick his foot in his mouth. He also has an interesting take on the cars he reviews. In other words, he’s an entertaining lummox. So, I thought I’d check out one of his books for a little light reading. This book is a collection of columns that Clarkson wrote for the “Sunday Times” and while there a few chuckles or “…hmmm…” moments within, most of it reads like “I’m a lout who gets paid to write and complain about things that annoy me, but I just can’t be bothered to worry about that right now.” Without the interaction with his TG co-hosts, Clarkson is just your stereotypical grumpy old man…only he has a book deal.

It's an odd business reading collections of newspaper columns years after they were published in book form, and an even odder business when they are Jeremy Clarkson's. In one of his pieces he writes about the jury system being flawed given that people who are stupid can be jurors. I feel a bit the same way about the availability of his work.There was plenty of the lowest common denominator contrarian posturing, although he's good enough with words that this is still reasonably entertaining (if you forget that some people will think this is serious comment). However, there was a surprising proportion of thoughtfulness. His piece on real university vs the university of life took a surprising turn, and his May 2003 column on Ebola made especially resonant reading now.

I know that Stonehenge is located on Salsbury plane and that Salsbury plane is a part of London that's very Ah ahh aah ah ah aaaaahhh. I know this because Eddie Izzard told me in a comedy routine several years ago. I know that in Britain the steering wheel is on the right side of the car and that Jeremy Clarkson is quite tall. I know that because I watch Top Gear. But, being American, that's about all I knew about the UK (which is not interchangeable with England, fyi)But despite that I still really enjoyed this collection of Clakrson's rants. And now I also know who John Prescott is. Which greatly helped me understand the last episode of series 16 of Top Gear.

A collection of his weekly columns in the UK's 'Sunday times' newspaper dating between January 2001 and December 2003, Jeremy passes his own unique judegement on a wide variety of topics.If you're not a fan of his irreverant 'take-no-prisoners, call-it-as-he-sees-it' attitude and writing style, then there are plenty of other books out there that might suit you better... on quilting perhaps? Or even flower-arranging...However, if you too find yourself continually frustrated by the boneheaded decisions made by small-minded busibodies who have made a career as fun-spoling bureaucrats and professional nay-sayers (or just if you're a fan of Top Gear) then this is the book for you.

Bigoted, opinionated, self-centred, obstinate and politically incorrect. I thoroughly enjoyed it. My fun when I read it was 5 star, but then I begin to worry, will people actually believe this? 4 stars. Then, do I sneakily wish I believed it? 3 stars. Finally, do I deserve to rate such bad (naughty, not badly written) book so highly. I guiltily give it 2 stars and move on. Sorry, Mr Clarkson, it's not you, it's me. And as no one else is likely to ever read this review, I have to be hard on myself and limit the rating. (Over 500,000 copies sold, and that was years ago. He won't even care. All the best, sir, and thanks for the laughs.)

This Book is a marvell....Got it in my hands first time 1 year ago, read 15 pages, got online and ordered 5 more....The subjects could be looked as dumb, usual, perfectly the opposite of intresting....Usual stuff in all. BUT THEN YOU GET TO READ IT...and every line is as enjoyable as the one before and lying forward....He makes funny everything in the way he presents it. You want to know how long his phone battery is usable...he won't tell 2 hours...But that the damn thing has the life expectancy of a veal-calf.Everything good in that book, really chil out stuff....Absolutely to read

There's something about Jeremy Clarkson that I can't quite put my finger on. Everything should suggest that I should hate him and not even want to pick up one of his books or watch one of his shows. But yet I do. His brand of tired misogyny and out of touch dad stupidity and his obsession with gas guzzling cars is everything that I hate. Yet I'm still drawn to him. Even some of his opinions I don't agree with. Yet I'm transfixed by his books, I laugh my balls off and sometimes even find myself agreeing with him. And I hate myself for it. His books are great though. There I go again. I mean, honestly...

Wins: British humor, quick 3 page articles meant I sped through the pages. Fails: I have no idea who the heck he's talking about most of the time. British politicians from the early oughts? Ok, His Tonyness, but everyone else skipped merrily over my head. Primarily, though, it was refreshing to read what was nearly conservative satire. Mr. Clarkson has definite opinions, and he has no qualms expressing his frustration with politics. It makes me wonder what my experience of the American discourse would be like if Jon Stewart and Jeremy Clarkson traded barbs.

For the past several months, I've been amused by the opinions and antics of Jeremy Clarkson and his colleagues on the motoring show Top Gear. So I've been sampling some of their writings. This book is a collection of Clarkson's columns from the early 2000's, so the references are a bit dated. I don't see eye to eye with Jeremy on much of his politics, but he does turn a few interesting phrases, and a couple of the pieces (such as the one on "blame culture") are spot on. He does know how to laugh at himself, which is always a good thing.

The famous British Philosopher Clarksonius is among my favorite people. We agree on nearly everything, and our body type is roughly the same. He's a hell of a funny guy, and some say Top Gear is my favorite show. BUT, it took me a while to get through this one. Yes, I laughed my ass off the whole way through it and loved every minute of it, it just didn't work as a book to me. My suggestion; use it as a toilet read. Nothing will make you $h!t faster than one of Clarkson's stories, and the discontinuity won't bother you so much.

I may not agree with everything Clarkson says, and he may be a conservative buffoon - but this was a thoroughly enjoyable book that had be laughing on the train. He also makes a lot of strikingly good points, too. At first I expected him to be constantly complaining about "today's youths" with their music and their baggy pants - a real "get off my lawn" kind of attitude - but it seemed to be the opposite, mostly. His point often seemed to be more "Stop being old bores, and lay off the NIMBYism". It's also much more enjoyable when you read the whole thing in his voice.

A jovially-written, entertaining, a great light-read. I really enjoy Jeremy Clarkson's humour. I have to say though, I find Clarkson (or 'Jezza' if you prefer) to be at his best on television, that is, on the television program 'Top Gear'. Perhaps it's his enunciation rather than what he actually says that draws me in, but I found that the frequency at which I was left in stitches by something he said was less in the written medium than in the audio-visual medium.

A collection of Clarkson's anecdotal articles from over the years. There were times I burst out with laughter, other moments where I didn't, but one thing is for certain: I smiled through every page.This is more of a coffee table book. Not to be read at once, otherwise you may end up with the Clarkson Syndrome yourself.Also, it would have helped to be British, or at the least European, to get every joke/anecdote in this book. I am neither, but I still found it very enjoyable.

I had no idea what to expect from this book- not even its format (a collection of Clarkson's articles). That may have tempered my mild disappointment. While I love Clarkson on Top Gear and his writing style, I found his rants somewhat boring after awhile. I still laughed aloud, but the book grows tiresome. I think this is best left as a bathroom read, and in that respect, one of the best I've ever read...

I love Jeremy Clarkson so I had incredibly high expectations for this book (otherwise it probably would've gotten 5 stars). Clarkson is absolutely hilarious on Top Gear, and although a slight bit of that is lost in writing The World According to Clarkson will make you laugh out loud for sure (especially if you enjoy British humor). It's a compilation of his editorials in the Telegraph, which I didn't expect, so if you go into it knowing that then you'll get everything you're expecting.

I have books a bit like this that reside in my bathroom. Light reading, short stories and amusing in parts. TO be honest, this is not good enough for my bathroom. Clarkson's observations are vaguely clever but full of his irritating smugness and self-glorification. The book is made up of re-prints of old newspaper articles and were out of date even when the book when to print.I borrowed the book from a book club for some holiday reading but I won't be back for more.

Move over Charlie Brooker- that's how I'd sum this series of books up.I am not one for celeb column books (most of them *cough Brooker* just like the sound and look of their own voice) but Clarkson's books just do it for me. He say what we are all thinking but don't feel we can say- ever. Funny, spot on, witty and intelligent, and broken down into diddy chapters (perfect if you are like me and have a busy life). This made me break my 'no non fiction' streak"

OMG! Hilarious. These are brilliant books if you like something in the bathroom. They are bite sized chucnks with each chapter being no more than 3 or 4 pages of Clarkson doing what he does best - ranting, maoning or pontificating. You might not like the bloke but you have to admire his forthright stance on many thing and I was actually surprised how many times during the book I was nodiing my head and agreeing with him, especially when he takes a pop at the beauracrats in our lives.

This book is a collection of Jeremy Clarkson of Top Gear's columns in the Sunday Times between 2001 and 2003. He muses on everything from Concorde's retirement to delayed flights in Spain. As usual, Mr. Clarkson is irreverent, frequently offensive, and more often than not just plan provocative. For the most part, he is quite funny and entertaining. I enjoyed it but it is probably not for everyone.http://www.books.rosboch.net/?p=1626

Wow this has taken me months to finish. As a person I quite like Jeremy Clarkson, I think he's funny and very intelligent and I like watching him on tele...when he's not talking about himself. These chapters are so short the moment he starts a ramble on a topic it's over and were on to the next. And everything is about him and his bias opinions. That said I did finish it and I will still watch him on tele. Oh no wait. He's been sacked!

This was the first Clarkson book I picked up, really I was too young at the time to get a lot of the references but the bits I did I found hilarious. I recently rediscovered my collection of Clarkson's books and was reminded how funny and accurate he really is. I know there are many who dislike him and to those I would say stay clear of the book, however for lovers of his work this book is excellent!

This is a collection of articles by Jeremy Clarkson, so it feels more like reading a newspaper or blog rather than a book. He is irreverent, politically incorrect, ironical towards everything (including himself), and hilariously funny even where I disagree with him. Trigger warning: at least one paragraph, possibly many more, will offend you (yes, you!) If you tend to take things too seriously, do not read.

For those of us who don't read newspapers, this is a collection of the columns that Jeremy Clarkson wrote. There are frequent references to British politicians and other personalities that escaped me since I don't live there, but nonetheless I found myself laughing heartily, out loud, a number of times. If you like that sort of sense of humour :)

blimey, you'd have thought Top Gear's Jeremy Clarkson had such a mix of conservative/liberal, sometimes anti-immigrant views! Sometimes I would find myself laughing, others I would be shaking my head thinking 'oh no, he didn't!' Still, a humorous read nonetheless...not sure I'll be picking up any of his other books though...will probably stick to watching him talk about cars ;)

Solid collection of columns from Jeremy Clarkson. If you're at all aware of the Top Gear TV series, you'll know if you're going to like this book or not. The humour here is exactly the same, although instead of cars he mostly makes fun of politics or British news in general. Apparently there are three sequels to this, which I'm sure are all almost exactly the same.

A really funny book - Clarkson is as witty, opinionated, and bigoted as he is on TV. And never afraid to offend! But it's not a book you want to curl up with in front of the fire. Its more of a book you dip into when you've got 5 minutes of spare time, or that you leave on your table for friends to pick up.

Jeremy Clarkson's columns fall into two categories: The car-centric ones, which are very entertaining, but a hard slog because you need to be up on every obscure marque of the past half century; and his non-automotive ones, which are a much faster read. Read more

Clarkson's book, I believe. are is a bit like Marmite - you either love them or hate them and unfortunately this one was too much ranting for me. I have read one before that was fine as it was observational but this was one just repetitive and dull. It's. Its not often I have a DNF but this one didn't give me any other choice.

Expected a bit more from Jeremy, to be honest. Started to even annoy me with some of his opinions - not being too provocative, but on the contrary too dull. But overall, funny reading and some of the pieces, mainly the one about Concord's last flight, were even touching. Won't probably read the sequels, though.

Eh. It's a collection of Jeremy Clarkson's newspaper columns. His normal bombastic, slightly offensive style is there, and it is mildly amusing. The problem is this is a one-man show, without Hammond or May to take him down a peg or two, which reduces the amount of humour possible. It's all right, I'd say I enjoyed it, and I went through it quickly enough. Can't say it was fantastic, though.

This had me laughing out loud on a ferry from Ireland to Scotland. The people around me were giving me some very strange looks. One man came up to me and asked what I was reading and when I showed him the book he went straight to the ferry shop and bought it, 10 minutes later he was sitting a few table from me laughing like a loon. Brilliant.

I know I only gave it 3 stars, and it's not because I didn't thoroughly enjoy Jezza's typical ramblings. His rants are always brilliant, it was just not a very easy read for my American self. I found myself constantly having to look up some of his more obscure British references that I didn't really have a problem with when I read Karl Pilkington. Apart from that it was a knee slapped!

Well it is a funny book from a funny guy. I like his daring approach and writing style which can become really ridiculous. Thats what it's all about. It touches some interesting and uniqe topics and its all written in Clarksons style. I recomendit if you wan't to read something fun and not overly politically correct.

"The World According to Clarkson" is a collection of short columns and essays written by Jeremy Clarkson of Top Gear fame. He's very tongue-in-cheek and nearly every essay had me chuckling. All essays in this collection are over ten years old, so they're a bit dated, but I can still appreciate his point of view and snarky British humor.

This was really funny in places but also quite interesting. I never knew donkeys needed passports, regardless of whether they were travelling or not. It was really easy to put down and pick up, and is probably best savoured in small doses. Typical Jeremy Clarkson and definitely a book I'd recommend to any men of my acqaintance.

Some "blog posts like" put into book. Defiantly not the best ones... Everything feels disconnected and there's no joy to read it. Could not finish it - felt like I wasting my time while reading this book. Stay away from books like this - no value in them. If you want to read one, better watch TV - same category - wasting the time.
Consists of excerpts and amusing anecdotes from Jeremy's column in the Sunday Times newspaper from January 2001 to December 2003.[http://thejumbledbox.blogspot.com/200...]

These are his newspaper articles so each is only 3 or 4 pages long which makes it great pick up/put down read.I was actually quite surprised that I enjoyed this book because he gets on my nerves a bit on the telly.

Read this book on a plane and got the kind of looks usually reserved for the parents of screaming children from chortling, guffawing, snorting, etc...Gonna learn something? Not likely, but it's a fun piece of fluff.

So it's only his articles gathered together and published, but it's still entertaining. I found this perfect to read over a week, picking it up now and again after work to de-stress with. It's quite random and amusing and he has such a way with words, it was enjoyable.

I picked this up off a hostel shelf with little else to turn to. It has a few laughs, but for the most part, it's uninspired conservative British tripe. At least he's self-deprecating. And he does drive jolly fast on Top Gear.

This is a collection of Jeremy Clarkson's (one third of Top Gear) newspaper articles on anything and everything (although he seems to have a particular thing for Concorde). He's a snappy, funny writer and this has some laugh out loud moments. Good light read for holidays.

Love Jezza to bits when it comes to entertaining us with cars on a Sunday night, but otherwise can Mr Murdoch ask JC to leave this and the Sunday Times Review section alone.... please! Will people please stop buying me Jeremy Clarkson books.

I hesitate to file this under humor. I hadn't realized what a troll Mr. Clarkson was. While a couple of the stories are mildly amusing, it's mostly page after page of blowhardedness and awful opinion.

While his witty remarks work well on Top Gear, in this book it just feels like a bunch of ranting clichés that gets boring after a few chapters. Nevertheless it has some interesting and funny takes on a few of the traits of British people that will make you laugh for sure.

An exellent book with hilarity oozing from its very spine, The World According To Clarkson will appeal to every age and every personality (except someone of the enviormentally caring persuasion). A top recommended read, one which everyone should read at least once before they die.

Clarkson's accounts of his xenophobia and the struggles of being a wealthy and privileged BBC presenter are entertaining in short doses for an hour a week two series a year. A book full of it gets a bit cloying.

I was surprised (and slightly worried TBH) by how many of Mr Clarkson's comments held within this book struck a chord with me. Funny commentary on our world today. Worth a read to remind yourself that you can't take life too seriously.

*lol* oh my god this book was absolutely fantastic! It really made me a Clarkson fan, whereas I was indifferent to him before. He's so snarky, and with the way he writes you can just hear his voice in your head.

He's no James May, but I'll likely read everything else by Jeremy Clarkson now! He's rather amusing, in an aggressive sort of way, and he makes some valid points. And made me cry over the Concorde. You couldn't ask for a better rec than that!

Mildly amusing. Jeremy Clarkson has done his best for the great cause of cheering us all up through trying to make a Formula 1 car out of bits of wood, driving a semi blindfolded, or any of the other damn fool things they do on Top Gear. I imagine this would work a lot better as an audiobook.

Clarkson is funny and the book is a good read to grab in between others, it will not get stuck in my head though. He mentioned Iceland twice and at least once positive. I suppose I would have loved it if I would have been a Top Gear Fan

A collection of Clarkson's hilarious collumns collected within one book? It's almost to good to be true. My favourite place to read is on trains and planes, and I felt myself laughing out loud because of this book on more then a single occasion, buy this, read this, love this.

Reading this book almost 8 years after the columns were written means that a lot of the current events and culture references were lost on me. Plus, I don't know many of the British people named. Some of the pieces were funny, and some were just cranky, but all of them were certainly Clarkson.

I have to confess that i didnt finish this book. Not a fan of Top Gear but thought id give his book a go but what a bore plus all i could hear in my head was his voice droning on and on ... and on! So after 100 pages - i quit!

It was an entertaining book; light reading, with short chapters and good ol' British humor. My husband warned me that nothing is sacred to Clarkson. He takes a jab at everything, from his own British culture to Nelson Mandela. He doesn't hold back.

Jeremy Clarkson, in written form, and without the other two to bounce off of. So, just like on TV, he's intelligent, argumentative, obnoxious, childish, and quite funny, but only a few of the articles really stuck out.

I don't agree with his politics and yes, he is a little arrogant... but I love him anyway. The book is hilarious and great for an easy read to pick up at short intervals and amuse yourself... say, on the toilet or whilst on hold with T Mobile...

He was all the rage in our household four years ago. Thought I'd see what all the fuss was about. Made me chuckle a couple of times in the way I'm prone to chuckle at The Grumbleweeds and Bobby Thompson. A reminder of where we were.

Very Humorous writing. But much of it is about British Celebrities/Politics/Locations which honestly I have no idea about. Must have been real fun to read when it appeared as articles on a newspaper every day. But a book for a non-European? No.

Not just about cars but Clarkson covers a wide spectrum of subjects in a witty, knowledgeable and entertaining way. A collection of all his Sunday Times columns - a really fun and surprisingly informative read.

This was my first dive into any of Jeremy Clarkson's books and I enjoyed it immensely! Despite being 10 years old, the arguments he brings up on numerous topics are still relevant and funny today!Already bought the second in the series

The host of BBC's Top Gear writes down some of his witty observations in short 2 page essays. He comically ponders everything from politics to fine dining to traveling to social etiquette. If you can get past some of his very British references, you'll find comedy gold! Reviewed by: Meg

Probably this is good just for spending sometimes during your flights. At least this is how I finished this book.I would not read it again nonetheless. The humor was ok. Some articles I did not get his intention.

This collection of newspaper columns is a light read that will make you laugh. Yep, that just about sums it up. If you want to read about a guy who ate too much beetroot and thought his reddish pee was a sign of prostate cancer - read on.

I've always loved Clarkson from Top Gear, but I had never read any of his writing until my most recent train journey. Turns out, he's just as funny in writing {if not moreso} than he is in person. A fun read.

I really like Clarkson on television, but this book is just a series of badly thought out rants that betray Clarkson's own lack of intelligence and humour. Very, very disappointing. However, it would make the perfect Christmas present for a father who both hates reading and people.

I thought that this book was really good in all. It didn't have too much information and it was manageable to read. To anyone who would like a break from fiction and wants to read a nice and comfortable book, this is a really good one.

you cant deny he's funny full of imaginations and gutts...but I find he is way too cynical, there's some truth in what he writes, but then maybe world will be a better place with less criticism and sacarsm such as his?...mixed feelings

A funny and easy read! Jeremy Clarkson is the kind of geezer I would love to have a pint with, this book is an easy read with some witty humour and a generous insight into the mind of a very funny, very opinionated man. Worth a read.

Jeremy Clarkson is absolutely wonderful and I love his sense of humor! I don't see why some people get offended at his humor as he insults everyone alike and it's brilliant. I plan on getting his other books and diving in!

Clarkson's Sunday Times pieces from 2001 to 2003. Much less enjoyable than his more recent musings -- or is it just that none of it ages well? Some of these columns will make even the full-on Clarkson fanboy wince. As always, however, a few gems.

Clarkson is hilarious! The World According to Clarkson is a collection of fun little articles, most of them being really short. I think because this was published over 10 years ago, there were many references to some occurancies that I missed. Still a very entertaining read.

Very Funny This book is compilation of articles Jeremy Clarkson wrote in the early 2000s. Very funny and interesting insight into the British mind. Love this book. If you love him on Top Gear and now on the Grand Tour you'll love this book!! I recommend it.

Years of watching Top Gear has given me a particular liking for Clarkson's humour (or like some may say, the lack of it). It was only imperative that i devour this collection of his wittiest articles to my complete satisfaction. I am yet to conclude whether he hates everyone, or, everything.
Typical Clarkson- funny essays on more than just cars.
so far this is great book, witty, funny and of course its Jeremy Clarkson, who I absolutely love
Light and funny reading. Book is a compilation of Jeremy Clarkson's Sunday paper articles. He loves cars, hates the French and Americans...and Brits in equal doses.
On reading on the loo...or in bath. Its essays or articles and perfect just to have a little think.
Hilarious - I love his arrogance and scarily found myself nodding and laughing in agreement with many of his thoughts!
like this one so much, i'm actually rationing it out a bit.
Fantastically amusing :)
He's much funnier on Top Gear.
Jeremy Clarkson being his normal self. Which is okay in hour lots tempered by JM and Hamster, but a bit much for a full book.
Classic Clarkson. His wit is an acquired or at least distinctive taste.
Very sharp, very British +++
Well, at least he seems to hate everyone with equality. However, I prefer his car works.
The world as seen through the eyes of a very outspoken, not-at-all humble motoring presenter. And by Gods its funny...
Jeremy Clarkson for Prime Minister!
i love top gear and thats all because of mr clarkson therefore i love this book. a funny man is indeed a sexy man.
I liked this book because it was easy to read and it had short chapters.I also liked it because of all the different things he talked about.I thought it was a very good book.
This is a decent book were Clarkson has his say about the world around him. Some of this is funny and some parts serous an all round classic.
Always good. Always a gadfly.
This one is hilarious, even though I'm reading his oldest edition. He just puts his ideas on to the writing and that's just cracking me up.
This was a good book but I got a bit bored with some of the stories. It was funny and I enjoyed reading it.
Good
Started off weird..barely raised a smile... turns out to be hilarious though.
Cynical, insightful, politically incorrect, and of course, hilarious.
What can I say, I love the man's sense of humor! A good dose of sarcasm / dry British humor is not wasted on me... =D
Comical though only in small doses or it gets samey. Typical irony, judgementalism, and narrow view of the world makes it very clarkson
As hilarious as the show he hosts, this book made me laugh my head off...A good example of british humor.
A fun read, despite the fact that it is somewhat topical and was written back in 2003. Clarkson is rather opinionated, but that is part of the charm and humour.
A brilliant, funny, fresh look on some things that happened at the time Jeremy wrote the columns collected in this book. A guaranteed laugh on pretty much every single page! :)
Well, Jezza is golden, isn't he?A bit obnoxious, but he's my spirit animal.
Was a funny read, but what a con. The book is just a reprint of his newspaper articles!
Enjoyed his rants not for everyones taste but entertaining
A very funny, witty and clever book, it actually had me laughing out loud in places.
A selection of Jeremy Clarkson rants.Love his sense of humour. A hilarious take on modern life littered with interesting information, delivered with his usual dry wit.
Got this as a Christmas present and was suprised how much it made me laugh.
Funny and unique take on things. You cannot agree with all Mr. Clarkson's opinions, but having sampled his humour on Top Gear, you can certainly laugh throughout.
a great funny book, will have more of his for sure
Really funny!! Really enjoyed!! Really recommend!!
Interesting opinions, but ultra Brit centric
The best of the bunch. The funniest articles he has ever written have been in this book. Some had me paralyzed with laughter. His others don't come close to matching this.
A funny book where you don't have to think that much. Ideal for vacations and when you read other more complex or even scary books at the same time.
Extremely witty, sarcastic and, if I'm allowed to use this description, British to the core. The mix of it made the book I thoroughly enjoyed.
Irreverent, non-PC and extremely funny. Clarkson bursts the bubble of pretentious Greens and Reds with sheer satire.Loved it; well, except for one or two really crude and blasphemous remarks.
If you do not know who Jeremy Clarkson is, you need to find out! This no nonsense Brit. has a way with words. I guarantee that portions of this book will make you laugh out loud.
Very amusing, I was either smiling or laughing when I was reading it.He is right about so many things...
I never realized what a strong writer Clarkson was. A very good read
Its a funny read but not really a book, more a collection of thoughts. This does mean you can pick it up and put it down without worrying about the flow of the book (as it doesn't)
Interesting essays, but I enjoyed May's work a lot more. Clarkson is just a bit too bitter at times.
If you like Jeremy Clarkson, you will like this book. We aren't talking fine lit here... Just a fun read.
Jeremy Clarkson's Sunday Time's column collected and published in one book where he talks about almost everything under the sun.
At times very funny.
Extremely funny. I was laughing in the bus while reading this almost all the time. Definitely a must read.
Very enjoyable! Great sense of humor and irony. Well done, Mr. Clarkson.
Damn near wet myself laughing. It was hysterical.
Good old wit that is pure Clarkson. Recommended for fans of Adam Carolla. Not always agreeable, not always easily transcribed into American English, but still fun.
Jeremy Clarkson is certainly entertaining to read, and he's better writing than hosting Top Gear, if you asked me!
I remember being amused at his expression "pillow breasted harridans" or something similar, which seemed very apt.
Clarkson at his best. With zaney stories and antics.
Fair
Not as funny as or as clever as P.J. O'Rourke. Good size articles to read in the toilet!
God, Jeremy is amazing writer.
He's sort of theBritish PJ O'rourke. Very funny, but can be an opinionated jerk.
Well, I can imagine Clarkson talking about these as he writes the stuff. A read that'll help you pass the time.
Love top gear so I thought I would give this a read as Jeremy is hilarious. Agree with 99% of his views. Cool guy.
I love Jeremy. His sense of humor, his outlook, just him in general. This book was perfect. I cannot wait to read the rest of this series.
Bit dated by now and some columns not cery relevant to me, but with nicu humour and some excellent views on everyday stuff.
Jeremy has an opinion, and he's not afraid to broadcast it ... with some very funny bits along the way. He has a very interesting way of looking at the world.
Hilarious. Jeremy Clarkson for president.
A good book but disappointing if one expects it to live up to the standards of Top Gear.
Ir says everything! :)
Nice read... short Sunday Times stories makes it good reading. Varied subjects... different perspectives. Concorde story is nice...hope they bring 'supersonic' travel back.
Amusing collection of his Sunday times articles, sometimes he is insightful and sometimes ignorant
eh eat the british muff ins :/
lacked any real sharpness. Perhaps he should stay on Dave.
I don't want to write a review,because I'm a fat lazy American. I enjoyed the book, it was okay. Okay?! Now, seven more words are required, seven.
Not just a good read....a great read!! Clarkson is the best!
Jeremy Clarkson attempts to cope with the real world. Very funny.
AMAZINGly funny book on everything wrong and right with the world.
A light but very funny read
Really Funny book. Lots of things to do with cars.
Got it free while bargaining for a Hebrew dictionary , so great :)
Sarcasm, irony and mega perfect wit!Jeremy Clarkson as he is in TopGear :)
brilliantly wordedlove the witvery original
An occasional snigger but not that funny.
Witty, amusing, relaxed holiday-like reading.
Can't find a better book to read while you are on a hospital bed with dengue. Funny to the core.
Easy going read ideal for relaxing and the occasional laughing fit.
Why does the war last so long in the middle east? Cause it never rains.What is the number 1 thing everyone should be afraid of? The acronym.Brilliant. Hilarious.
A simple, often funny, view on the world of 2001 to 2003. All articles are taken from his column in the Sunday Times. Worth a read, if only to see how the world, and he, has changed
Entertaining
i know i shouldn't but i do.
Funny bits of British humor.
GERMANY IS VERY NICE
Very funny, witty and silly.
Very Very funny, I have laughed out loud at a lot of parts and is a very good book for a light read
You can read one of Clarkson's books in an afternoon-- handy vacation books.
Funny and entertaining!
Great toilet read - Clarkson at his usual amusing self.
Amusing and perceptive.
Very good to dip into when you can't sleep.
As an American living in England, I can't possibly give this any more stars.
Light hearted fun. Obviously a bit trashy.
I haven't finished it :-/

Entertaining and very funny in places. I've never come across someone so enamoured with Concorde so much before and the casual jokes about seal clubbing/wanting a water fountain of Hitler killing an otter sound so far removed from being funny it's untrue but such is JC's humour. You either like it or you don't and on the main I find his comments funny but generally not things I'd think about too often afterwards.

I'm really surprised at how much I laughed out loud while reading this book, despite the fact I don't always agree with Clarkson on some major issues. He writes very well and humorously. It was written in 2001 - 2003 so I didn't always follow some of the govt administration columns because I was an Australian teen at the time but enjoyed it none the less. It's light-hearted and just fun to read.
